awd_titl_txt: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Incorporating Sociotechnical Cybersecurity Learning Within Undergraduate Capstone Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
All technology professionals require basic proficiency in cybersecurity.  However, typical computing curricula do not require any courses in cybersecurity.  As a result, a majority of students graduate without any proficiency in cybersecurity relevant to the systems they will develop and use when they join the workforce.  Moreover, cybersecurity electives often cover only technical topics, and technology professionals must understand how cybersecurity is influenced by social factors.  This project will fill this curricular gap and will develop, deliver, and evaluate a suite of sociotechnical cybersecurity learning modules.  These modules can then be used in standard computing curricula to create a cybersecurity proficient software workforce that can significantly enhance cybersecurity in the workplace.

The modules will be used in capstone courses at Informatics at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) and Indiana University (IU).  The researchers will utilize the modules to create an assessment for the most critical and essential cybersecurity knowledge and skills. The outcomes of the research will advance the understanding of how students could develop sociotechnical cybersecurity proficiency as a part of their capstone experience.  Since capstones are typically a graduation requirement, integrating cybersecurity learning within these courses will have the transformative effect of all students in the computing disciplines graduating with core cybersecurity knowledge.  As a part of the research activities, several cohorts of undergraduates will receive cybersecurity training useful for their professional careers.  The learning modules and assessments will be openly available to other educators and institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The research funded by this award resulted in the design and implementation of learning modules for students in the computing disciplines to learn the fundamentals of technical and social aspects connected to security and privacy issues associated with the technical solutions they design and implement. The investigators delivered these modules to several cohorts of a multi-term undergraduate capstone course in which student teams develop real-world technical solutions for external clients from industry, non-profits, academia, or government.


Intellectual Merit:

The award supported the creation and delivery of ten learning modules on the fundamental technical and social aspects connected to cybersecurity. In addition, the researchers developed a cybersecurity knowledge assessment to measure knowledge of fundamental technical and social aspects connected to security and privacy considerations in technology. Evaluating the cybersecurity learning modules via the cybersecurity knowledge assessment showed that the modules were successful in helping students in the capstone course learn and apply sociotechnical cybersecurity concepts in their respective projects when compared with other sections of the capstone course without the learning modules. The outcomes demonstrate that capstone courses in the computing disciplines can be leveraged to ensure that all computing undergraduates acquire foundational cybersecurity knowledge prior to graduating and joining the technology workforce.

The researchers additionally studied the collaborative practices of the capstone project teams to compare their experiences when in-person instruction switched to online mode in the middle of the course because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The study revealed that the students (i.e., novice software developers) found online collaboration more challenging compared to their project sponsors (i.e., experienced industry professionals). The challenges faced by the students point to several avenues for training novice software professionals to engage more effectively in geographically distributed collaboration, which is increasingly the norm in the technology industry.


Broader Impacts:

The findings of the research supported by this award produced two publications at top-tier venues in computing education and group work. The ten learning modules and the Cybersecurity Knowledge Assessment created under this award are freely and openly available for use by instructors of capstone courses in the computing disciplines. Over the course of the award, the researchers delivered the modules to more than 200 undergraduates, most of whom have since joined the technology workforce. In addition, the award provided research opportunities for several undergraduate students in the computing disciplines.


Last Modified: 03/26/2025
Modified by: Sameer Patil
